title: Thunderclap Headache in a Middle-Aged Female

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.text: Ms. Rivera, I can see you're in a lot of pain. Can you tell me exactly how this headache started and when?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.text: It hit me like a bomb went off in my head. I was just sitting at my desk at work about three hours ago and suddenly I had the worst headache of my entire life. It came on in seconds, not gradually. I've never experienced anything like this.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.text: That's a very important detail. On a scale of 1 to 10, what would you rate the pain? And have you had any nausea, vomiting, or sensitivity to light?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.text: It's a 10 out of 10, easily. I threw up twice on the way here. The light is bothering me terribly, and I feel like my neck is really stiff and sore. I can't bend my chin to my chest without it hurting badly.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.text: Have you noticed any changes in your vision, any weakness or numbness in your arms or legs, or any difficulty speaking?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.text: Yes, right before the headache I saw these weird flashing lights and then part of my vision went blurry on the right side. My left eyelid also seems to be drooping. I do get migraines sometimes, but this is nothing like my usual migraines. This is completely different and so much worse.

dialogue.speaker: doctor
dialogue.text: Have you had any recent head trauma, and do you have any history of high blood pressure? Are you on any medications, including blood thinners?

dialogue.speaker: patient
dialogue.text: No head trauma. I do have high blood pressure but I ran out of my amlodipine about two weeks ago and haven't refilled it. I'm not on blood thinners. My mother had a brain aneurysm when she was 50, which really scares me.

gold_standard_questions.question: How suddenly did the headache reach its maximum intensity?
Is this the worst headache you have ever experienced?
Do you have any neck stiffness or pain with neck flexion?
Have you experienced any visual changes, including blurred vision, double vision, or visual field loss?
Do you have any drooping of the eyelid, pupil changes, or facial asymmetry?
Have you had any nausea, vomiting, or photophobia?
Do you have any weakness, numbness, or difficulty with speech?
Have you had any loss of consciousness or seizure?
Do you have a history of migraines, and how does this compare?
Is there a family history of aneurysms or subarachnoid hemorrhage?
What is your blood pressure history, and are you currently taking your antihypertensive medication?
Have you had any recent head injury or trauma?
Are you on any blood thinners or anticoagulants?
Did anything specific trigger this headache, such as exertion, straining, or sexual activity?
Have you experienced any fever or recent illness?

red_flag_questions.question: Did the headache reach maximum intensity within seconds to minutes?
red_flag_questions.reason: Sudden-onset, maximum-intensity headache (thunderclap headache) is the hallmark presentation of subarachnoid hemorrhage from a ruptured cerebral aneurysm, a neurosurgical emergency with high mortality if not treated promptly.

red_flag_questions.question: Do you have neck stiffness or pain when bending your chin to your chest?
red_flag_questions.reason: Neck stiffness (meningismus) in the setting of thunderclap headache strongly suggests subarachnoid hemorrhage with blood irritating the meninges, requiring emergent CT head and lumbar puncture if CT is negative.

red_flag_questions.question: Have you noticed any changes in your vision, such as loss of part of your visual field or blurred vision?
red_flag_questions.reason: Vision changes with thunderclap headache may indicate an expanding aneurysm compressing the optic nerve or chiasm, vitreous hemorrhage (Terson syndrome), or raised intracranial pressure, all requiring emergent neuroimaging.

red_flag_questions.question: Is there any drooping of one eyelid or difference in pupil size?
red_flag_questions.reason: A new third cranial nerve palsy (ptosis, mydriasis) with severe headache is highly concerning for a posterior communicating artery aneurysm, which may be expanding or actively rupturing.

red_flag_questions.question: Have you had any loss of consciousness, confusion, or seizure?
red_flag_questions.reason: Loss of consciousness or altered mental status with thunderclap headache suggests significant subarachnoid or intracerebral hemorrhage with potential for rapid neurological deterioration.

expected_consult.reasoning: A 40-year-old female presenting with thunderclap headache (worst headache of life with sudden onset), meningismus, visual changes, and ipsilateral ptosis with a family history of cerebral aneurysm has a clinical presentation highly suspicious for subarachnoid hemorrhage from aneurysmal rupture. This requires emergent CT head, CT angiography, and neurosurgical consultation. If CT is negative, a lumbar puncture must be performed to rule out subarachnoid hemorrhage.
